importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The planned opening date of the exhibition at CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain, when the Picasso painting was supposed to go on display.
The day before the exhibition was set to open, when the delivery of artworks, including the Picasso piece, was scheduled to occur.
The date when the disappearance was reported to police and when the official investigation was initiated.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the painting was expected to be on display at the cultural center.
The period when the delivery of the artworks took place and the delivery was scheduled to be signed off.
The period when the police investigation began and the missing artwork was reported.

keyTakeAways: A Picasso painting, 'Still Life with Guitar' (1919), went missing during transport to a temporary exhibition in Granada, Spain.
The painting was insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000) and was delivered via a van to CajaGranada Cultural Center on schedule.
All deliveries were under video surveillance, and no incidents were detected during the weekend prior to unpacking.
The painting was reportedly missing when staff began unpacking it on Monday, October 13, 2025.
Spanish police have launched an investigation into the disappearance and have added the artwork to the international database of stolen artworks.
Picasso's works are historically high-value targets for theft, as seen in previous recoveries in the Netherlands, Greece, and Belgium.
There is currently no international police cooperation being conducted to recover the painting.

namedEntities.name: Pablo Picasso
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The painting is a work by Pablo Picasso, one of the most renowned artists in history, making the disappearance particularly significant in the art world.

namedEntities.name: Still Life with Guitar
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This specific 1919 gouache painting is the central object of the missing artwork incident and is central to the narrative of the article.

namedEntities.name: CajaGranada Cultural Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the exhibition was supposed to take place and where the painting was delivered and discovered missing.

namedEntities.name: Granada
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The city in southern Spain where the cultural center is located and where the incident occurred.

namedEntities.name: Spanish Police
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The authorities investigating the disappearance of the painting and initiating the official inquiry.

namedEntities.name: Transportation Company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The company responsible for delivering the artworks to the cultural center, which transported the Picasso painting.

namedEntities.name: International Database of Stolen Artworks
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The system used to track and report stolen art, into which the missing Picasso painting has been added.

namedEntities.name: Dutch Art Detective
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A reference to the recovery of Picasso's 'Portrait of Dora Maar' in 2019, showing a precedent of successful recovery in the Netherlands.

namedEntities.name: National Art Gallery in Athens
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where a prior heist occurred in 2021, highlighting Picasso's art as a target for theft.

namedEntities.name: Belgian Police
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The authorities who recovered a Picasso painting, 'Tête,' in Antwerp in 2024, showing a pattern of theft and recovery.

namedEntities.name: Saudi Sheikh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The owner of the yacht from which a Picasso painting was stolen in 2019, illustrating a high-profile theft case.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 1919 Picasso painting titled 'Still Life with Guitar' vanished during its scheduled delivery to a temporary exhibition at the CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain. The artwork, valued at 600,000 euros, was delivered via a transportation company under video surveillance and was set to be displayed starting October 9, 2025. Staff discovered the painting missing when unpacking began on Monday, October 13, after confirming no incidents occurred during the weekend. Spanish police have launched an investigation, and the artwork has been reported to the international database of stolen artworks. Given Picasso's history of being targeted by thieves—such as in the Netherlands, Greece, and Belgium—this disappearance is part of a broader pattern of art heists involving his most valuable works.
title: Picasso painting goes missing en route to exhibition
